Fig. 1 (a) Pathway for the preparation of edge-confined MoS2. INT for intermediate, TS for transition state. Reaction formulae for each step and the specific names of the intermediates (INT) are indicated in SI. (b) Charge transfer of Mo before and after the first H transfer. (c) COHP diagram of the Mo-H bond formed between the second H and Mo before and after the transfer of the first H. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Phenol adsorption modes over single Mo active site of edge-confined pristine MoS2. (a) Single Mo active site on edge-confined pristine MoS2. (b) Aromatic ring flat adsorption mode. (c) CAr-O bond top-on adsorption mode. (d) CAr-O bond side-on adsorption mode. (e) Aromatic ring side-on adsorption mode. S, light yellow; Mo, purple; O, red, H, white; C, brown. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 DDO reaction pathways of phenol over MoS2 edge. INT for intermediate, TS for transition state. Reaction formulae for each step and the specific names of the intermediates (INT) are indicated in SI. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Adsorption energy (Eads) of TM@MoS2 SACs. (b) Relative formation energy (Ef) of TM@MoS2 SACs. (c) Periodic Table of Elements, orange indicates doped transition metals (TM), blue indicates screened-out transition metals. (d) Histogram of C-O bond cleavage energy barriers of transition metal doped TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Hf). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 DDO reaction pathways of phenol on Fe@MoS2, Ru@MoS2, Tc@MoS2 edge active sites. Structural snapshots of the reaction transition states were performed. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Linear-scaling relationships between C-O bond cleavage energy barrier and (a) ∆q (in e); (c) d (in Å) and (d) Ψ (in e/Å). (b) Electron transfer distribution of TM@MoS2. Blue areas indicate negative electron transfer, yellow areas indicate positive electron transfer. Fig. 6 Rational design of MoS2-supported single-atom catalysts for enhancing phenol deoxygenation: Unveiling synergistic electronic-geometric effects and a universal structure-activity descriptor Jiehang Wei Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Xin Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Tao Ma Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Shouqin Mu Writing – original draft Formal analysis Yingtao Liu Writing – review & editing Project administration Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Utilization of Coal and Green Chemical Engineering, National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Ningxia University, Yinchuan 750021, China State Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Utilization of Coal and Green Chemical Engineering, National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Ningxia University Yinchuan 750021 China State Key Laboratory of High-Efficiency Utilization of Coal and Green Chemical Engineering, National Demonstration Center for Experimental Chemistry Education, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Ningxia University, Yinchuan 750021, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Exploring rationally descriptor is pivotal yet challenging in designing single atom catalysts. By doping single atoms (such as 3d, 4d and 5d transition metals) on the MoS2 edge, efficient activation of the C-O bond in phenol is achieved. The study finds that the doped metal not only modulates the electronic structure of the C-O bond through electron effects but also restricts the adsorption mode of phenol through geometric effects. Based on these findings, a simple linear relationship Ψ, defined as degree-of-cleavage descriptor, was proposed. This descriptor quantitatively captures the combined impact of electronic and geometric effects and establishes a direct correlation between the descriptor and catalytic activity. Importantly, it comprehensively accounts for the combined effects stemming from the metal atoms in the active center and the MoS2 edge support. Graphical Abstract Keywords Selective direct deoxygenation Single atom catalyst Descriptors First-principles calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As the global population expands and industrialization progresses rapidly, there is a continual surge in energy demand and environmental stressors. Therefore, it has become particularly urgent to find and develop sustainable alternative energy sources and materials. Biomass lignin, recognized as a natural, renewable and abundant resource, is increasingly becoming a focus of attention from both in research and industry[1–5]. The conversion of lignin into value-added chemicals and fuels requires three processes: lignocellulose fractionation, lignin depolymerization and value addition[6]. However, the high oxygen content in lignin makes it less attractive as a chemical material compared to petroleum. Lignin, as a complex cross-linked macromolecule, consists of a large number of benzene rings connected by ether (CAr-O) and carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds, necessitating the dissociation of C-O bonds for its conversion into monomers[7–9]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), a proven method for converting lignin-derived phenols (e.g., phenol, p-cresol and guaiacol) to arenes, has undergone years of investigation to improve the bio-oil quality[1,2]. So far, the challenge part is finding out catalysts to realize the highly selective hydrogenolysis of the C-O bond and inhibit hydrogenation of the aromatic ring (namely direct deoxygenation, DDO). This is because the energy barrier of C-O bond dissociation far outweighs that C-C bond and CC bond hydrogenate[3,4]. Accordingly, the development of efficient DDO catalysts with direct C-O bond cleavage selectivity is crucial for the hydrodeoxygenation process of phenols to arenes. MoS2-based catalysts are excellent choices for the HDO of lignin because they are more favored the DDO route rather than the hydrogenation (HYD) route[5,10–13]. On the other hand, many advantageous on single-atom catalysts (SACs), such as unprecedented catalytic activity and selectivity exist, which are urgently need for DDO reactions[14–18]. Therefore, the combination of metal single atom and MoS2 is expected to bring better catalysts for DDO of phenols. An attempt of isolated Co atoms that bond covalently to sulfur vacancies on the basal planes of MoS2 was used to drive HDO of 4-methylphenol to toluene by Tsang et al[5]. They achieved a high activity, selectivity and stability which allows the reaction temperature to be largely reduced. Another attempt of regulating the surface of MoS2 dominated by Wu et al. via substituting Pt4 + for Mo4+, exhibited 100 % oxygen removal at a low temperature of 120 °C[10]. To balance the selectivity and reasonable catalytic activity, an effectively strategy is to confine adsorption mode by regulating metal single atom and 2D MoS2 monolayer. Lou and his coworkers designed and fabricated edge confined Rh1/MoS2 and Pt1/MoS2 SACs[19,20]. It was found that the pocket-like active sites can efficiently convert biomass-derived crotonaldehyde to crotyl alcohol because the confined adsorption mode of crotonaldehyde formed by steric hindrance effect yields 100 % selectivity. Zhao and colleagues have also designed Steric-Confinement Rh diatomic active centers, which show a unique spatial restriction effect to selectively activate specific CO bonds for efficient ethanol production[21]. However, the traditional catalyst development process is often time-consuming, costly and relies on empirical trial-and-error methods, which hinder the rapid market iteration and make it challenging to quickly screen and identify the optimal thermal catalysts from a vast array of candidate materials. Selective dehydrogenation reactions have been extensively investigated with transition metal catalysts, including Mn [22], Co [23,24], Zr [25], Nb [26,27], Mo [22,28,29], Ru [30,31], and Rh [30,32]. However, considering the high time and trial-and-error costs associated with traditional catalyst development, computational screening of transition metal single-atom catalysts not only accelerates the catalyst development process but also disrupts traditional research paradigms through data-driven rational design. This makes computational screening a critical tool in materials science research, as it accelerates progress by efficiently simulating and analyzing materials and reaction processes[26,29]. In this process, descriptors serve as an important bridge between experiment and theory. The choice of descriptors holds significant important, as they can quickly screen out candidate catalysts with potential capabilities. Starting from the electronic and geometrical properties of the dopant, Meena et al [26]. established a linear scaling relationship between four simple descriptors and the catalytic performance of the doped Mo2C catalysts. Their findings revealed Zr- and Nb-doped Mo2C were the most promising catalysts with enhanced HDO catalytic activity. Wang et al [33]. constructed a structural descriptor containing both electronic and geometric effects, and this descriptor was presented in the form of formula to classify and reorganize the roles of electronic and geometrical factors in the kinetics of acetylene semi-hydrogenation, leading to the final identification of Pd1Nb3 and Pd1Hf3 with high ethylene yields and low cost, which were validated by experimental studies. Xia et al [34]. established a theoretical relationship between hydrogen capacity/rate and structure of heteroatom-doped graphene-loaded light-metal Li monatomic materials for efficient solid-state hydrogen storage, forming a volcano peak curve with double inflection points different from a single linear scaling relationship. An excellent descriptor should contain the electronic and geometric properties of the microenvironment of the active site. Additionally, the descriptor can be a property of the dopant itself or a combination of aspects to come up with a formula. In this work, phenol is used as a model compound to simulate the properties of phenolic compounds extracted from biomass. To lower the activation energy barrier for C-O bond cleavage, TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Hf) were constructed to modulate the activity of MoS2. Based on density-functional theory calculations and computational screening, we further propose a descriptor Ψ to correlate the energy barriers of C-O bond cleavage with electronic and geometrical effects to provide a strategy for screening the best single-atom catalysts. 2 Calculation method All the structural relaxation and the adsorption correlation energy calculations were performed by using the spin-polarization density generalized function theory method implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP)[35,36]. The electron-ion interactions and exchange-correlation interactions were treated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional[37,38]. In this paper, the MoS2 monolayer crystal of p (4 ×4) supercell was constructed, and the plane ( 0 1 ̅ 00 ) was cleaved to obtain the Mo-edge, which contains 4 Mo atoms in the x and y directions and 1 layer in the z direction. The lattice constant of the two-dimensional (2D) MoS2 supercell was 12.66 Å× 9.17 Å. To eliminate the interaction between the layers of the periodic system, a 15 Å vacuum layer was set. Based on Monkhorst-Pack scheme, the Brillouin zone was sampled with 3 × 1 × 1 K-mesh, and a cutoff energy of 400 eV was used for plane wave basis set. In addition, all the structures were fully relaxed by using the conjugate gradient method until the maximum Hellmann–Feynman forces acting on each atom is less than 0.03 eV/Å while the electronic convergence limit was set to 10−5 eV. With a time-step of 1 fs and a total simulation time of 10 ps, ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) calculation was carried out using canonical ensemble (NVT). Climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method and Dimer method were used for searching transition states (TSs), and each transition state was verified to have only one virtual vibration frequency along the reaction coordinate direction. The formation energy of TM@MoS2 SACs ( E f ) was calculated by: (1) E f = E sys Mo x T M y S z − xμ Mo − yμ TM − zμ ( S ) Among them, E sys Mo x TM y S z is the total energy of TM@MoS2 SACs, x, y and z represent the number of Mo, TM and S atoms, while µ(Mo), µ(TM) and µ(S) represent the chemical potential of Mo, TM and S atom. The adsorption energy ( E ads ) of the surface species is defined by (2) E ads = E total − E phenol − E baresurface Among them, E total represents the total energy of phenol adsorption over the catalyst, E phenol represents the energy of phenol in the gas phase, and E baresurface represents the energy of catalyst substrate. The activation energy barrier ( E act ) of primitive reaction is calculated by (3) E act = E TS − E IS Where E TS and E IS are the energy of transition state and initial state. The reaction energy ( E rxn ) in the elemental reaction is calculated by the formula. (4) E rxn = E FS − E IS where E FS is the energy of the final state. According to the calculated absorption energy ( E ads ), reaction energy ( E rxn ) and activation energy barrier ( E act ), the energy pathway of HDO reaction of phenol on TM@MoS2 SACs was drawn. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Restricted adsorption of H2 and phenol 3.1.1 Fabrication of Edge-confined MoS2 In this work, the optimized structure of the Mo-edge terminations is illustrated in Fig. S1. Initially, we investigated the thermodynamic stability of the Mo-edge by performing ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations at 500 K, as shown in Fig. S2. The root-mean-square deviation (RMSD) value over 10 ps to assess the topological equivalence of the structures was calculated. The results, evident in Fig. S2, reveal minimal deviations during the simulation, and the relaxed structures from the AIMD output do not exhibit bond breaking. These findings confirm the thermal stability of the structure over the 10 ps simulation period. Actually, the Mo-edge of 2D MoS2 nanosheets that's been stripped can get sulfurized pretty easily, and then it can oxidize right after[19–21]. The energetic pathways involved in the formation of both sulfurized and oxidized MoS2 edges, as illustrated in Fig. 1a. The sulfurized MoS2 edge has a formation energy of −2.68 eV and can undergo further oxidation by releasing 1.38 eV, resulting in the formation of an oxidized Mo edge. This spontaneous fabrication process leads to a structural transformation where the O species bonded to Mo atoms tend to adopt a dangling oxygen configuration, leaving single atomic Mo exposed. This change enables oxygen to function as a baffle, potentially restricting the adsorption of hydrogen and phenol. The following is a discussion of H2 and phenol hydrodeoxygenation on edge-confined MoS2. 3.1.2 H2 activation Fig. 1a illustrates the H2 dissociation process. Specifically, the Mo atom is selected as an active site on which the H2 molecular can be preferentially adsorbed and dissociated with energy of −0.44 eV and −0.27 eV, respectively. In the process of H2 dissociation, the H protons are transferred to the dangling oxygens by breaking the Mo-H bond. The calculated energy barriers for H transfer are 0.22 eV and 1.33 eV, respectively. The significantly higher barrier for the second H transfer arises because the first transfer alters charge distribution around Mo active site. Bader analysis (Fig. 1b) shows Mo loses 1.26 electrons before this transfer but gains 0.64 electrons after, changing the local electrostatic environment and thereby raising the barrier for the second H transfer. From the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Populations (COHP) perspective, the strength of the remaining Mo-H bond increases after the first H transfer (Fig. 1c), leading to a higher energy barrier for the second H transfer. Following H2 dissociation, a unique baffle structure consisting of oxidized edges and OH groups formed by dissociated H atoms is formed, which is denoted as edge-confined MoS2 in this work. Compared to the previous O atom, the OH group has a greater baffling effect to limit the adsorption conformation of phenol. This is consistent with the experimental studies by Lou et al., who previously demonstrated that a special pocket-like HO-Mo-Rh(Pt)1-Mo-OH structure can be formed using a modified strong metal adsorption method[19,20]. The following is a discussion of limiting adsorption of phenol on edge-confined MoS2. 3.1.3 Edge-confined MoS2 for limiting adsorption of phenol The possible adsorption modes of phenol on the edge-confined Mo active site are screened and displayed in Fig. 2. As shown in Fig. 2a, the distance between the OH moiety of the edge-confined MoS2 is 5.45 Å. While the length and width of a phenol molecular are calculated to be 5.60 Å and 4.58 Å, respectively. The flat adsorption mode therefore was excluded, considering the steric repulsion of OH moieties (Fig. 2b). By contrast, the phenol can be easily adsorbed on Mo atom via CAr-O bond top-on adsorption mode (Fig. 2c), and of course the CAr-O bond side-on and aromatic ring side-on adsorption modes (Fig. 2d and e) are also possible. Table S1 shows adsorption energies of the three adsorption modes. Quantitatively, the CAr-O bond top-on adsorption mode has an advantage of −0.08 eV compared to aromatic ring side-on adsorption mode. Although the adsorption energy of the CAr-O bond side-on adsorption mode is relatively low, this adsorption mode seems unlikely to occur because of the thermodynamical instability. Accordingly, the aromatic ring side-on and CAr-O bond side-on adsorption modes are negligible. Therefore, the adsorption configuration of phenol on the edge-confined MoS2 can be effectively defined in the direction that is conducive to the activation of the CAr-O bond. 3.1.4 DDO catalytic performance To get more detailed insights into the characteristics of catalysts, the DDO reaction of phenol on the Mo active site was investigated from the CAr-O bond top-on adsorption mode. The energy pathway and corresponding structures were displayed in Fig. 3. The key step in the DDO reaction of phenol is the production of phenyl (C6H5*) and hydroxyl (OH*) intermediates by the direct C-O bond dissociation. As shown in Fig. 3, the energy barrier of C-O bond direct dissociation on the edge-confined MoS2 is 1.47 eV. During the subsequent C6H5* hydrogenation process, the dissociated C6H5* group prefers to transfer to the neighboring OH moieties outside the edge Mo atoms and is exothermic by 1.59 eV. There is no transition state formed in this process, indicating a spontaneous transferring of C6H5* group upon the edge of MoS2. Then, the H of OH moiety transfers to the C6H5* group by breaking the O-H bond, forming a benzene molecular (C6H6*). According to the calculation, the energy of subsequent hydrogenation is −0.24 eV, indicating that hydrogenation is spontaneous. Therefore, the aromatic benzene can be facilely obtained once the phenyl intermediate is formed. This is also a good indication that the phenol DDO pathway over the edge-confined MoS2 is feasible. 3.1.5 Regeneration of catalyst The OH* group is left on the position of Mo atom when benzene desorbs from the Mo active site. The subsequent hydrogenation of OH* is conducted via another OH moiety acting as a baffle on the Mo edge of MoS2. Here, the H from OH is transferred and subsequently combines with OH* to form water. This process has a reaction energy of 0.21 eV, as illustrated in Fig. 3. Finally, the edge-confined Mo active site on Mo-edge of MoS2 is regenerated by the desorption of H2O molecular. 3.1.6 Evaluation of catalyst Hence, edge-confined MoS2 catalyst was designed to use the OH moieties at the edge as a baffle to restrict the upright adsorption of phenol onto the active site Mo, resulting in a good selectivity for the direct deoxygenation of phenol to benzene. However, the energy barrier for C-O cleavage remains relatively high compared to that previously calculated by our research group for MoS2 supported catalysts[39]. This is primarily because transition metals (TM) usually exhibit high catalytic activity, which can effectively reduce the activation energy of the reaction and thus increase the reaction rate. Based on this, we will further introduce the transition of metal single atoms into the edge-confined MoS2 catalysts, expecting to improve their activities on the basis of having good selectivity. 3.2 Heteroatom doping and descriptor−activity relationship 3.2.1 Doping TM on the MoS2 edge A wide range of transition metals from the 3d (Sc, Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn), 4d (Y, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag), and 5d (Hf, Ta, W, Re, Os, Ir, Pt) series were systematically doped into the edge-confined structure of MoS₂, replacing the original molybdenum (Mo) sites to create active sites with enhanced catalytic properties. The fundamental crystal structure of MoS2 remained intact as the dopant atoms were integrated, resulting in the creation of TM@MoS2 single-atom catalysts (SACs). 3.2.2 Adsorption of phenol Phenol was adsorbed onto single-atom catalysts designed with transition metals doped at the edges of MoS2. It was found that only TM@MoS2 SACs, where TM represents Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, and Hf, were effective in adsorbing phenol. This suggests that phenol adsorption is governed not only by the OH groups at the MoS2 edges but also significantly influenced by the structural characteristics of the doped transition metals. The adsorption energies of the selected TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, and Hf) catalysts are shown in Fig. 4a. It can be seen that the adsorption energies of the selected catalysts are all negative, indicating that these adsorption processes are thermodynamically spontaneous and exothermic. By analyzing the charge density differences across all doped surfaces (Fig. S3), a significant electron transfer between the dopant metal and the MoS2 edge can be observed. This electron transfer is instrumental in stabilizing -OH groups, as it enables the transition metals to accept electrons from oxygen. Additionally, an examination of the densities of states (DOS) of TM (Fig. S4) shows that the adsorption active sites stem from defect states and orbital hybridization near the Fermi level. The analysis of the charge density differences and DOS confirms that the adsorption sites in TM@MoS2 SACs are closely related to changes in the electronic structure, which subsequently modulates the catalyst's intrinsic activity. Following the initial screening process to identify effective catalysts, the stability of the selected TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, and Hf) was rigorously evaluated. Formation possibilities and structural stability were assessed to exclude unstable candidates. Fig. 4b compares the formation energy of these TM@MoS2 SACs and pristine MoS2, making it is possible to get an idea of their formation possibilities. Pristine MoS2 has been experimentally synthesized and is stable, and is therefore used as a reference value for the upper limit, while the relative Ef value (defined as Ef (TM@MoS2) - Ef (MoS2)) is used to estimate the likelihood of TM@MoS2 formation. Clearly, the negative relative Ef values for the TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, V, Mn, Fe, Co, Zr, Nb, Mo, Tc, Ru, Rh, and Hf) indicate that these structures can be realized experimentally. Fig. S5 also shows that the TM@MoS2 SACs were subjected to AIMD at 500 K, respectively, and the root mean square deviation (RMSD) values were calculated for 10 ps, which indicated that these structures could remain thermally stable. To visually represent the doped transition metals, we display them in the periodic table in Fig. 4c, with orange representing transition metals that can be doped and blue representing screened-out transition metals. 3.2.3 Activation of phenol’s C-O bond The phenol's C-O bond cleavage process was systematically examined based on the adsorption structure of the TM@MoS2 SACs catalyst. The structures and associated energies of the initial, transition, and final states of the phenol's C-O bond cleavage were documented in Tables S2 and S3. A comparative analysis of the energy barriers for C-O bond cleavage across different TM@MoS2 SACs was conducted. It was noted that the energy barrier underwent significant modification due to the doping of the TM active site, a finding that is visually represented in Fig. 4d. The energy barrier for phenol C-O bond cleavage increases from the unmodified 1.47 eV to 1.52 eV when V is used as the active site, indicating that the C-O bond is not well activated in the V@MoS2 catalyst, and therefore we will not discuss V@MoS2 catalyst in the subsequent sections of the descriptors. In contrast, the incorporation of Ru and Tc was found to markedly reduce the activation energy barrier for C-O bond cleavage to 0.67 eV and 0.70 eV, respectively. This substantial decrease indicates an improvement in the catalytic activity of Ru@MoS2 and Tc@MoS2 SACs. It is noteworthy that phenyl hydrogenation on Tc@MoS2 occurs naturally, with intermediates rather than transition states present during the reaction. However, Tc's radioactivity and associated risks make it an unsuitable candidate for an active catalyst site. Regarding Ru@MoS2, examination of the DDO pathway showed that the high energy required for dehydration (1.46 eV) makes this step thermodynamically unfavorable. As a result, both Ru@MoS2 and Tc@MoS2 are deemed unsuitable choices for the phenol DDO catalyst. Subsequently, the Fe@MoS2 and Rh@MoS2 catalysts acquired our attention due to their relatively low activation energies. Although both catalysts exhibit the same energy barrier of 0.85 eV for phenol C-O bond cleavage, the Fe@MoS2 significantly more cost-effective. In the quest to identify effective DDO catalysts, a detailed examination of the phenol DDO pathway over Fe@MoS2 was conducted to ascertain the optimal candidate ( Fig. 5). It was found that Fe doping into MoS2 not only reduced the energy barrier for phenol's C-O bond cleavage to 0.85 eV but also lowered the dehydration energy to 1.03 eV. This dual reduction in energy barriers enhances the catalytic efficiency of Fe@MoS2, making it a superior choice for the phenol DDO process. Following the identification of the optimal catalyst for phenol hydrogenation-deoxygenation, the formation mechanism of the OH-containing baffle structure on Fe@MoS2 was investigated (Fig. S7). The process was initiated by sequential sulfidation and oxidation of the Fe@MoS2 catalyst, with reaction energies of −2.02 eV and −1.97 eV, respectively. Subsequently, the adsorption and activation of H2 at Mo edges of the pre-treated Fe@MoS2 were examined. As depicted in Fig. S7, Fe atoms were identified as the primary active sites, with an H2 adsorption energy of −0.53 eV. During the H2 dissociation process, the H proton transfers to the lone oxygen atom via the breaking of the Fe-H bond. The energy barriers for H transfer were calculated to be 0.65 eV and 0.93 eV, respectively. Although the second H transfer energy barrier is larger, the overall H2 dissociation reaction energy is −0.19 eV, indicating that it is thermodynamically favorable. 3.3 Descriptor−activity relationship 3.3.1 Based on the electronic theory Dopant atoms, particularly Fe among the 3d series and Ru and Tc among the 4d series, significantly influence catalyst activity by altering the activation energy barrier. Active sites in catalysis are generally categorized by their electronic and geometrical effects. However, the intricate interplay between these effects makes it challenging to understand how the electronic and geometrical modulations of the active site impact the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over TM@MoS2 SACs. In order to study the electronic regulation of surfaces, geometrical effect is minimized. From Table S4, it can be seen that the atomic radii of the six elements, Ti, Tc, Ru, Rh, Nb, and Mo, are in the range of 125–132 pm, with a maximum of 7 pm. Therefore, TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Ti, Tc, Ru, Rh, Nb, Mo) with similar atomic radii were selected to study the electronic effect. Herein, electron transfer (∆q) between phenol and the catalyst is classified as an electronic effect, which affects the energy barrier of the C-O bond cleavage, the key step in catalyst screening ( Fig. 6a). We have calculated the COHP of the C-O bond of phenol before and after adsorption. The change in the electron density of the C-O bond can be observed quantitatively by COHP analysis. Integration of the portion of the COHP curve below the Fermi energy level shows that the integral value of the antibonding state of the C-O bond of the phenol before adsorption is less than zero, which indicates an overall antibonding (Fig. S6). In contrast, after phenol adsorption on the active site, the negative value of the antibonding region of the phenol C-O bond decreases with electron transfer, indicating the weakening of the antibonding state. At the same time, the positive value of the bonding region may increase, indicating an enhancement of the bonding state. In summary, electrons in the antibonding orbital of the phenol C-O bond are transferred to the active site of the catalyst, resulting in a weakening of the antibonding state of the C-O bond and a gradual enhancement of the energy barrier of the C-O bond after adsorption. On the other hand, although the C-O bond itself is polar, in the phenol molecule, this polarity does not result in the C-O bond itself acting as an electron-withdrawing group. Instead, the polarity of the C-O bond is somewhat weakened due to the conjugation effect and the entire hydroxyl group provides electrons to the benzene ring through conjugation. However, when the electrons are transferred to the active center, it makes the polarization of the C-O bond increase, making the electrons more tightly bound to the oxygen atom and thus more difficult to break. 3.3.2 Descriptors based on the geometrical theory To quantitatively study the geometrical modulation of the active site, it is desirable to eliminate the interference of the electronic environment. Charge transfer in the active site is an important electronic environment, and Rh, Tc, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ru all lose electrons (Fig. 6b and Table S5). Therefore, the model TM@MoS2 SACs (TM = Rh, Tc, Mn, Fe, Co, Ru) was developed. The intrinsic geometrical descriptors of the C-O bond length of phenol(d) correlate well with the activation energy barriers for C-O bond cleavage (Fig. 6c). The C-O bond lengths of phenol on different catalyst surfaces are listed in Table S6. A longer C-O bond suggests a weaker interaction between these two atoms. This phenomenon can be attributed to the redistribution of electronic density around the C-O bond, which weakens the bond and facilitates its cleavage. Additionally, the transition state for bond cleavage, which is a high-energy intermediate state, becomes more easily accessible. This means that a longer C-O bond in phenol facilitates a lower activation energy barrier for its cleavage, making the bond-breaking process more energetically favorable. This relationship between bond length and dissociation energy highlights the critical role of the catalyst’s atomic composition in optimizing catalytic processes, providing a pathway for the design of more efficient catalysts for phenol-based reactions. 3.3.3 Data-driven equation for degree-of-cleavage Studies of the electronic and geometrical modulation of the active center have shown that electronic effects section (∆q) and C-O bond length of phenol(d) can electronically and geometrically influence the activation energy barrier for phenol’s C-O bond cleavage, respectively. To effectively quantify these influences, an interpretable descriptor, called degree-of-cleavage, is proposed here: (5) ψ = ∆ q / d where Ψ (in e/Å) is the degree-of-cleavage, ∆q is the change in electronic charge (in e), and d is the C-O bond length (in Å). The newly defined descriptor Ψ quantitatively integrates the synergistic effects of electronic and geometric factors governing activation energy barriers. Physically, Ψ represents the charge transfer density per unit bond elongation. Furthermore, it can be interpreted as the electronic activation efficiency of the bond. The computational results establish that reduced Ψ values correlate with lower E a , thus providing a systematic framework for predicting and optimizing catalytic activity. The relationship between the activation energy barrier (E a ) and the degree-of-cleavage (Ψ) can be expressed through a linear equation: (6) E a = kψ + b where E a is the activation energy barrier (in eV), Ψ is the degree-of-cleavage (in e/Å), k and b are coefficients specific to the reaction. Under different circumstances, k and b may have slight differences, reflecting the characteristics of different models. However, it is worth noting that regardless of how the model changes, k is always positive. By definition, an increase in Ψ correlates with an increase in the energy barrier for the cleavage of the phenol C-O bond, indicating a proportional relationship (Fig. 6d). This indicates that the electronic structure brings about a greater effect when activating the C-O bond, a result that is obvious because the specific structure of the catalyst limits the effect brought about by the geometrical environment. This relationship is crucial due to the C-O bond cleavage is often the key step in the overall reaction. It can help us screen out the most suitable catalyst for phenol hydrogenation dehydrogenation. The degree-of-cleavage descriptor, therefore, not only predicts but also optimizes the catalytic activity of various metals by leveraging their electronic and geometric properties. Consequently, Ψ serves as a bridge between theoretical calculations and practical applications, streamlining the process of catalyst design and selection. 4 Conclusion In summary, we emphasized a unique geometric structure, formed by the integration of the transition metal active site with OH moieties on the Mo edge of TM@MoS2 SACs, that selectively constrains phenol to an adsorption mode conducive to direct C-O bond cleavage. Through comprehensive calculations of relation of C-O bond cleavage energy barrier and geometric and electronic structure of catalysts, a straightforward descriptor, Ψ, is defined as an indicator of the catalytic efficiency of the active site. This descriptor provides a direct and intrinsic method for assessing catalyst activity, simplifying the selection of appropriate dopant atoms through standard chemical references. Finally, the edge-confined Fe@MoS2 single atom catalyst, which selectively constrains phenol to an adsorption mode conducive to direct C-O bond cleavage，was identified as an excellent catalyst for phenol DDO reaction. We hope this work will offer valuable guidelines to accelerate catalyst development in the realm of bio-oil upgrading. coredata.dc:description: Exploring rationally descriptor is pivotal yet challenging in designing single atom catalysts. By doping single atoms (such as 3d, 4d and 5d transition metals) on the MoS2 edge, efficient activation of the C-O bond in phenol is achieved. The study finds that the doped metal not only modulates the electronic structure of the C-O bond through electron effects but also restricts the adsorption mode of phenol through geometric effects. Based on these findings, a simple linear relationship Ψ, defined as degree-of-cleavage descriptor, was proposed. This descriptor quantitatively captures the combined impact of electronic and geometric effects and establishes a direct correlation between the descriptor and catalytic activity. Importantly, it comprehensively accounts for the combined effects stemming from the metal atoms in the active center and the MoS2 edge support.

coredata.dc:title: Rational design of MoS2-supported single-atom catalysts for enhancing phenol deoxygenation: Unveiling synergistic electronic-geometric effects and a universal structure-activity descriptor
